bestBHT.bht: Believing it was expedient and in their best interest, the leaders decided that one man should die for the people. Their concern was primarily for the preservation of the nation, rather than recognizing the spiritual significance of the sacrifice. Little did they know that their words unwittingly testified to the priestly and kingly roles of Christ, as God's plan unfolded through their actions. Just as the death of Christ had far-reaching effects on humanity, their decision served a greater purpose in God's divine plan.

Albert Barnes: It is expedient for us - It is better for us. Literally, 'It is profitable for us.'"
If he was put to death they supposed the people would be safe.
It was expedient, it was infinitely desirable, that Jesus should die for that people, and for all others, to save them from perishing.
Marvin Vincent: People - nation [του λαου - το εθνος] . The former the theocratic nation, the people of God : the latter, the body politic. See on 1 Peter 2:9.
Archibald T. Robertson: It is to your interest and that is what they cared most for.
That one man die...as the succeeding clause shows and as is clearly so in Galatians 3:13 of the death of Christ and naturally so in 2 Corinthians 5:14; Romans 5:6.
Politicians are often willing to make a sacrifice of the other fellow.
John Gill: Nor consider that it is expedient for us, that one man should die for the people."
Common prudence, and the public safety of the nation, required him to fall a sacrifice."
The main thing to be considered in such a council, so he thought it was, that the whole nation perish not.
John Wesley: It is expedient that one man should die for the people."
So God overruled his tongue, for he spake not of himself, by his own spirit only, but by the spirit of prophecy."
And thus he gave unawares as clear a testimony to the priestly, as Pilate did to the kingly office of Christ.

bhtAttempts.bht: The leaders of the nation, concerned primarily with their own interests, believed it was expedient for one man to die for the people. Their focus was on the political and national implications rather than the spiritual significance of this sacrifice, as further evidenced by the death of Christ and its effects on humanity. In their calculations, sacrificing one individual seemed to serve the greater good of preserving the nation. However, little did they know that their words unwittingly testified to the priestly and kingly roles of Christ, as God's plan unfolded through their actions.

Believing it was in their best interest and in order to protect the nation, the leaders determined that one man should die for the people. Their focus was on the preservation of the body politic, rather than the spiritual significance of the sacrifice. However, their words unknowingly bore witness to the priestly and kingly roles of Christ, as God's plan unfolded through their actions. The death of Christ and its implications for humanity were foretold, making clear the necessary sacrifice for the sake of all.

Believing it was expedient and in their best interest, the leaders decided that one man should die for the people. Their concern was primarily for the preservation of the nation, rather than recognizing the spiritual significance of the sacrifice. Little did they know that their words unwittingly testified to the priestly and kingly roles of Christ, as God's plan unfolded through their actions. Just as the death of Christ had far-reaching effects on humanity, their decision served a greater purpose in God's divine plan.

Believing it was in their best interest, the leaders focused on the preservation of the nation and concluded that one man should die for the people. They did not consider the spiritual implications of the sacrifice, but little did they know that their words unknowingly bore witness to the priestly and kingly roles of Christ. As God's plan unfolded, the death of Christ held great significance for humanity. Their decision served a greater purpose, aligning with God's divine plan for salvation.

Believing it was expedient for the nation's sake, the leaders determined that one man should die to preserve the people's safety. Their primary concern lay in the political and national implications, rather than the spiritual significance of the sacrifice. However, unknowingly, their words testified to the priestly and kingly roles of Christ in God's grand plan. Through their decision, the death of Christ became a pivotal moment with far-reaching effects for humanity. Their actions aligned with the divine purpose of salvation.
